description: From Latin verbōsus (“prolix, wordy, verbose”) + English -ose (suffix meaning ‘full of; like’). Verbōsus is derived from verbum (“word”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *werh₁- (“to say, speak”)) + -ōsus (suffix meaning ‘full of, overly, prone to’ forming adjectives from nouns).. Equivalent to verb + -ose.

adjectives.description: verbose (comparative more verbose, superlative most verbose)

entries.meaning: Containing or using more words than necessary; long-winded, wordy. [from 17th c.]
(computing) Producing detailed output for diagnostic purposes.
